critique: This executive order focuses on improving the management of information systems within the federal government. It emphasizes efficiency, strategic application of technology, and interagency cooperation. There's a strong emphasis on using technology to improve government performance and service delivery. The order establishes the CIO Council and other boards to coordinate efforts and share best practices. It also stresses accountability and performance measurement. There is nothing about immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The order promotes a more efficient and coordinated federal government through better use of information technology. It seems to promote some degree of federal control through the establishment of councils and boards. It also seems to promote some degree of deregulation by encouraging agencies to determine if the private sector should support certain functions. It does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt.
